posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I just saw a comment under a youtube video that mentioned making ethanol at home. I was looking and I found information that you can make ethanol at home by fermenting starches.

Out of curiosity I googled to see if dead leaves that fall on the ground in the fall have any starch in them.

I found this old article that seems to indicate dead leaves might be ten percent starch.

https://www.jstor.org/stable/pdf/43476796.pdf

I found this page talking about much dead leaves weigh.
https://www.lawnsite.com/threads/weight-of-leaves.484330/

They estimate 22lbs of dead leaves per thousand square feet.

So possibly you might get 2 lbs of starch per thousand square feet of leaf covered ground.

I also found this page, talking about making ethanol from corn.
https://www.e-education.psu.edu/egee439/node/672

It says a bushel of corn would yield 31.5lbs of starch or 2.8 gal of fuel ethanol. So it seems that 31.5 lb of starch must be able to make 2.8 gal of fuel ethanol.

So 11.25 lbs of starch must make 1 gallon of fuel ethanol.

So being conservative, maybe we could say 16lbs of starch from dead leaves might yield a gallon of fuel ethanol.

This would be equivalent to the leaves covering 8,000 square feet.

This is 0.18 acres to get one gallon of fuel ethanol.

I know this is not very much, but given the vast amount of dead leaves in the fall, I wonder if someone could find an economical use for the leaves? The raw material is something that most people are actively trying to get rid of. There are plenty of landscaping companies that are getting paid to haul leaves away from peoples' yards.

I wonder if there is a way to get some use from all those leaves?

>I wonder if there is a way to get some use from all those leaves?
There are plenty of uses for dead leaves. They are easily composted. You can mulch them. You can till them into your soil to provide nutrients for whatever you're growing. You can spread them around plants as a barrier to stop weeds.

Using them to make ethanol is the dumbest thing I've read on here all day. It would cost you way more to make your one gallon of ethanol than it would to go to the gas station and buy a gallon. Making ethanol at home is for farmers who have a shitload of leftover corn. Plus, ethanol only works in certain vehicles so it's not even a useful product.

My fees broke down to cars being one price and SUV/Van/truck being a different price. I would either do the interior, the exterior or both. Interior I could usually do in 2 hours maybe 3. and exterior would take almost 4 hours. car interior was 100 and exterior was 125. For the van/truck/suv the fee was interior 125 and exterior 175. But this was 8 years ago, no idea what I would charge now

I had basic wash and wax stuff, and a machine buffer. For interior I had a vacuum and a steam cleaner. All my products were either meguairs or Griots. I always used microfiber cloths never rags. Microfiber cloths were thrown away after jobs I never washed them. On a full inside/outside I could usually get done in 6 or 7 hours. But if I had a van or something that was really fucked up it might take 8 hours.

Biggest tip is to take some before and afters and use social media as your word of mouth advertiser. Make damn sure that every single customer you work with posts something about you on either facebook or next-door and puts your phone number out there. Also get 500 flyers for your services off vista print.

No an LLC is a waste of time for the money you are gonna make. Just have them pay you cash and don't put the cash into the bank.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525332
I started a mobile auto detailing business. I use a Rigid 5HP 4gal, one of their cheapest ones but the suction is great. You can get three uses out of each filter bag by cutting an end open, emptying it, and stapling it shut again. I also use Ridgid’s car cleaning kit which comes with an orange hose that is longer and softer, and a flexible crevice tool. These are essential. Throw in some kind of rubber brush or textured rubber glove for scooping up dog hair and you’re set on vacuuming.

For steam I use a McCulloch MC1375, great little machine. Saves a lot of time on cleaning if you learn how to use it. Takes 5-15 minutes to heat up depending on ambient temp and can last for two interiors. I’ve had a couple plastic bits break but it still works great. Be careful not to spray steak behind transparent plastic windows on dashboards and centre consoles. Oh and let the steam machine warm up before you start your vacuum or you will trip your client’s breaker.

I would also recommend you pick up a Bissel spot pro wet extractor for shampooing. Takes more passes than a commercial machine to get the job done but it works, and you can keep your vacuum dry and clean in the long run.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Years ago, a hurricane knocked down every power line in sight, and my power was still off after 5 days. I had work, though, so on day five I'm coming home and see lights on all over the place, and I'm pissed because I know mine will still be off. It's raining, and you can hear thunder, so no way they're doing anything at the moment. I come around a curve and see three trucks with the booms up, working in the rain with lighting in the area. Later on, I decide that if we ever have another disaster I'll go around and see if I can do any favors for a crew.

Fast forward to the ice storm of the century, and again it's about day five of freezing weather with no power, and I'm driving to the store and I see guys huddled in the cab of their truck. "Can I get you anything, sausage biscuit, or what." One guy holds up a BoJangles box like he's sick of biscuits, and then another guy says he could use a drink because he's about to dry out since they're restricted to their hotel at night. It's about dark, and they say they'll be there for another half hour or so (this is right next to our neighborhood), so I go get a case of cold beer and some Jack Daniel's and some vodka. I come back and they are there, but they caution me to not show it since an asshole in the next truck will report them, so we stow it in a box and after a bit more work they leave.

About 15 minutes later they're back, and they take an hour or so in darkness to get our power back on.

>>2509382
see pic rel for basic idea that applies to all pieces I made. I dunno how you would print that. Gonna paste my an explanation

It consists of a backer plate (9 light + 9 heavy layers), porcelain shards and a topper (3 +3) encasing the ceramics. Wanted to use 2 offset layers of ceramics, instead I placed the first and additional shards on what I deemed crucial parts of the armor.

This is the basic method for all armor parts I made, a full plate with porcelain for my mask, forearms and torso, the rest consists only of the backer type plate, 18 layers of sandwiched light and heavy glass cloth.

Made a visor from 1cm thick polycarbonat. Went trough some trial and error while attempting to heat bend it. Made a bubble free curved piece with our oven, the trick is to heat it up to 150c first and frequently open the door to let out steam, after a while turn it up to 175c. I want to thank thermoplastic anon for that info again. Another thanks to soap bar anon, scrub a bar of soap then wipe with a dry towel on glassy surfaces like glasses you don't want to fog up with your breath, it really works.

>>2509676
show examples of how this could be made, 3d printers are definetevly cool, but I noticed a trend where people will simply assume that a printer can print anything. How would you measure out your face this way? I did with simple gypsum bandages. And then print it how? Carbon fibres? For costs, a 33cm x 33cm rectangle plate costs about 15€ in material costs, the groin plate has this size. thats 9 + 9 patches of the heavy a d light glass filament. 1m2 can be cut into 9 patches. 1m2 of glass weave costs about 3-5€, so about 3 for the light and 5 for the heavy, 8€ total for the weave. Epoxy resin can be expensive, cheapest I found was 11€ per kg. for a 33cmx33cm plate with 18 layers of mixed weaves I needed 750g of epoxy, so about 7-9€ or something. Now you got a basic plate for what 15-20€. Porcelain is the best worst ceramic for balistic protection, you can source that for free. Add another glass weave for spalling protection above that to stop porcelain fragments from flying everywhere and boom you got a decent plate I'd say. 25€ max.

>>2511923
the protective gear part is a different beast. the orthopaedic gear is to prevent knee injury from missteps or non optimal posture. same goes for the lumbar belt.
even the cheap aldi versions do their job.

joint injury is the number one eliminator of modern troops.

for the fit: add a padded comfortable belt strap with some semi-rigid plate support. this way you circumvent the spine being loaded and free your lungs more. putting padding on the shin lower side, so it rests better on the shoe, can make the bug a feature.

some light knee pads could help with the armor and hard knuckle or sand gloves would add some necessary hand protection.

for the groin plate: try to cut it int an inverted trapezoid (basicly upside down chest plate shape). then it moves more easily when walking. the two removed pieces can be added as belt flaps/ armor skirt pieces.

>>2513688
For maximum efficiency, cut the fat out and chop it into ~1cm cubes. Put it in a pot with some water to cover and heat it to a simmer. After a few hours all the fatty acids will be rendered out of the tissue, then you sift the chunks out and let the liquids harden. The fat layer separates and floats on the water. To clean it just scrape the grimy bits off the bottom of the solid fat layer and put it back in a pot with fresh water and a generous handful of salt, bring it to a simmer and stir it a bit, let it cool and repeat until pearly white. Finally melt the fat down and insert a wick. There you go, odorless human candle.
Human fat is about 7700kcal/kg which is a lot better than wood pellets which generally sit around 4300kcal/kg. You only need a small fraction of that energy to refine it.

To make soap all you need to do is weigh your human tallow, then bring it to about 50°C. Take 26.82% of your fat weight in distilled water and 13.41% in pure lye and dissolve it in the water (do it with good ventilation or die). It will heat to almost boiling so let the mixture come down to around 50°C also, then dump it in the liquid fat and blend it with an immersion blender until it turns into a sort of paste. Scoop that out into whatever mold you like and let it sit for a day, then demold it and let it air dry for 2-4 weeks.

Why teflon? Why bedliner for bonding? Line X actually is bombproof, mythbusters made a vid about that, discussed this in thread #1 or 2 I think. The company by the same name actually has a specialized type of coating called pax- something. They use that for bombproofing government buildings. But you can't simply buy either of these products in a can. A shame. Only certified paintshops who are in contract with Line - X get that stuff and are allowed to coat projects wih it.

For the teflon, I just don't know what it would acclompish. I've seen a vid where a dude made a pauldron with glass filament + carbon fibre layers. But carbon sucks. Glass fibre cloth is simply the cheapest.

I wrote ZNA productions and techthisoutmeow multiple times, donated to their patreon. Wanted them to build and shoot test panels with my method. Mentioning it again, 9 light + 9 heavy layers and additionally porcelain + another 3 heavy and 3 light ontop. No further responses for about two months or so.

But thankfully a german hansguns offered to test it for me, I'll be sending him 2 such testpanels after xmas. I've gained some doubts of the success of my plates delivering what I hope for, because I did something different. I didn't vacuum press the plates during curing. My theory is, the epoxy itself should stay where it is and not be pressed out excessively. Further, I think a pressed conventional plate has it disadvantages too. The layers are already then pressed together and it' s maybe easier to penetrate them this way.

Only live tests will show if my theoretical method has advantages over singular type of weave pressed plates. If I had something like military interest funding, I'd research this matter more troughly, but I'm a literal neet lmao.

So I actually made a plate like this when I was a teenager. I took a piece of polycarbonate, placed ceramic tiles on top and then laminated the whole thing with many layers of fiberglass and polyester resin. Then I went to a gunfag board and asked some one to shoot it for me.

The results were not good, basically the only thing that didn't penetrate fully was .22LR. I don't remember exactly what he shot it with but I recovered the jacket of a large caliber pistol, possibly 45ACP and a small rifle round, most likely .223. Simply put, ceramic tiles are not hard enough to stop rifle rounds and while they may be able to fragment pistol rounds, they then turn into shrapnel that blows right through the backing. The whole thing was too stiff to work even as 3A armor and while polycarbonate is very tough, it cannot withstand the high impulse of a bullet impact, it basically tore open like a flap and let everything through.

Thinking realy hard, I came up with something.

BAM! Shrapnel protection for children. Reading about it on https://wikipedia.org/wiki/Flak_jacket

During the Korean and Vietnam wars, the flak jacket was changed and the manganese steel plates were replaced by other materials.[5] The U.S. Army's vests (Body Armor, Fragmentation Protective, Vest M69) weighed under eight pounds and were made of 12 layers of ballistic nylon. The vests used by the U.S. Marines (Vest, Armored M-1955) weighed more than ten pounds and were a combination of ballistic nylon layers and fiberglass plates known as Doron.[3] Doron was made of fiberglass fibers placed in an ethyl cellulose resin under high pressure. It was named after then-Colonel Georges F. Doriot, then director of the Military Planning Division, Office of the Quartermaster General.[2]

The generation of armor developed in the 1970s through the National Institute of Justice incorporated layers of soft armor in the form of DuPont’s Kevlar fabric, which has since become synonymous with ballistic protection and a general term used for several similar (aramid-based) materials.[6]

sewed 12 layers of the light fiberglass inbetween an inner and outer patch of cotton cloth. It's flexible like thick clothing. Intention is to make a type of cloak a child could wear. So it can't be too heavy and I hope it offers atleast minimal protection, similiar to a Splitterschutzweste (fragmentation vest?). Real Bundeswehr Splitterschutzweste paddings have 12 layers of kevlar appareantly. Theres is this guy 'tactical dad', a german autist with a very informative blog. If my sewed panel can stop atleast one 9mm it'd be more than enough, but I've a slight feeling it won't even handle weaker cartridges. base plate like top right, porcelain shards encased in 3 heavy + 3 light glass and epoxy. All my previous pieces are curved, this one's flat. After 14 hours the epoxy was still workable. Sticky surface. Was able to turn the cloth around on the entire edge.

My wife asked me about my progress, while explaining I think I got a good explanation of my method. Instead of applying pressure during curing, I let it rest. I imagine it like a towel hanging in the air, the weave is relaxed and stabbing it the towel will conform to the knife before it rips trough. If you stretch the same towel from all sides, the fibers are already under stress and one can stab it more easliy. More factors come to mind, for example having the surface covered while pressing it cuts of the workpiece from air which maybe intrerfers with the curing process. Can epoxy cure in a vacuum?

Regardless, only practice will show

I want to add a heated steering wheel to my old Honda. I found a heated steering wheel cover at a local liquidation store for $10 and I have a spare steering wheel laying around, pic related. After disassembling the cover I've found it's basically just some thick, insulated wires stitched into a felt backing. My plan is to gouge out some channels in my spare wheel in which I'll lay the wires and bed them with some sort of heat-resistant epoxy, then I'll tap power from my horn/cruise control buttons and wire in a switch. posts.name: Anonymous

>>2537926
>Nice to keep the old iron going. Did you have to make or raise the opposing jaw? Reminds me I was trying to make a vise some years ago with a trailer jack... I'll need to revisit it soon, probably derust it at this point.
>You're right, I need to determine the thread pitch. Just reinitiated the acme vise nut search, which there's quite the range in price. I'd be willing to modify if necessary, just need the baseline.
>Saw some postings asking a lot of $$ for Sawyer Tools vises.

No I was able to fit the dynamic jaw to the static jaw before pinning and welding it to the slide I made. Like I said this vise wasn't really even that great of a vise to start with. It had a hollow jaw casting and I was able to take some plate steel and stick up inside that jaw and then drill through and pin it, then weld everything up...

Most vises aren't actually an acme thread, most of them use a square cut thread. An acme thread is tapered and just flat on top and bottom. I did use an acme threaded rod and nuts to fix mine, because I could source it easily.

You should be able to knock that pin out of the inside of your vise body and then knock what is left of the vise nut out.

I built my own tapered piece of steel to fit into my vise body, then took two acme nuts and added a spacer to make them work. Tacked them into place when I thought I had them good, and then ran the slide in and out to make sure it was properly centered before fully welding it up. My vise had a bolt keeping the nut from backing out of the taper instead of the pin like yours has. You can see the two acme nuts I used in the pic above.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2537926
Oh and if you do end up going the acme threaded rod route, make the screw go all the way to the end of the slide. Most of the time the end of it is back in the slide a couple inches and this limits the width the vise can open. I wouldn't recommend clamping anything with a ton of force with it fully extended, but it's nice to have the option to at least hold something wider at times.

posts.sub: Old ass fuse box in my garage
posts.com:
Bought a house this summer and this is the fuse box in my garage. I was not thinking the other day and ran my old table saw and an electric heater on the same circuit and popped one of the glass fuses. I replaced the blue 15 amp fuse that was visually blown but the outlet and entire circuit that I wanted to use was still dead. I pulled the main and range boxes and tested the continuity of the shotgun shell looking fuses and they all worked fine. I then took my tick tracer and saw that the red 20 amp glass fuse had no power to it, but the other three blue ones were fine. The red 20 amp fuse doesn't look blown like the one I replaced did.
I'm confused. I'm a low volt guy so I know a little, but not a lot about higher voltages.
1. What's going on here?
2. Can I pull these glass fuses and main/range boxes without walking back to my house and killing the power to my shop, or will I get zapped? I'm not super scared of 120, but I'd like to avoid it if possible.
3. The guy before me left a more modern used panel in the garage, seems like he intended to switch it out and never got to it. I have a buddy who is a licensed electrician but lives about an hour away, is this something I could safely swap out with some facetime help from my buddy?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2537372
>the red 20 amp glass fuse had no power to it
Can still be bad even if it looks good. Its pretty simple shit. If there is power going to the fuse, but none coming out, it's a bad fuse, otherwise its further downstream.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2537372
pulling out main fuses will keep you from getting zapped without killing power at the main house panel, as long as you aren't touching the lugs or wires upstream of the main/range fuses thatcome in from the top. Sometimes the little round fuses just need to be tightened counterclockwise slightly. They aren't blown, but they loosen just enough to break the circuit sometimes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2537378
I'm a professional architectural engineer, specializing in elec design, as well as former electrician and this is the answer. just put a multi on either end of the fuse to rule it out. do not use a voltage detector or tracer. It will pick up anything near an electric field, and they are unreliable.

2. please do no work on this until you kill the power to it... theoretically you should be able to just pull the fuse. But this shit looks jank, and old, and you're already having problems.
Be safe not dead.

3. As far as you swapping out the panel - I'm hesitant to say yes if you don't understand how fuses work. No offense. Sub feeds get tricky, don't know where you're at but it could require a permit. and by the looks of that old ass feeder no licensed electrician in their right mind would land that shit back on a new panel. So maybe just do it anyway so you can learn and get him to make final connections and inspect?

>>2540317
This is a meme. Fuses take time to trip just like breakers, because they have to get hot enough to melt the thin wire inside.

The real reason home fuses are unsafe is because all the different amperages are interchangable. An idiotic homeowner will keep blowing a 15A fuse and replace it with a 30A fuse to keep it from blowing again. This isn't so easy to do with breakers, and you can just flip them to reset.

>this window
I'm pretty sure that's a door.

Anyway, yes you can paint the glass with latex paint if you want. Removing it would be as easy as scraping it off with a razor blade. Just clean the glass real good first or it may not adhere well.

You could also use some sort of window frosting, either spray-on or film, if you'd like to still have light come through.

If appearance isn't a concern (which I'm guessing it's not based on what I see in your picture) buy some foam-core board from an art supply store, cut it to fit the glass, stick some aluminum foil to the outward-facing side of it with some spray-adhesive, and hold it in with some good tape around the edges, like the metal foil tape used on HVAC ducts. Not only will the aluminum foil reflect a lot of the heat, but the foam-core board will provide some insulating value as well.

>egg cartons
>soundproof panels
That's for absorbing echoes inside the studio. And is generally expensive. Any isolation is merely a pleasant side effect.
>moving blankets
Now you're talking. You want heavy and rough/soft. The idea is to absorb the energy of the sund waves mechanically. Thick blankets are for lower frequencies. Small cell foams are good for high frequencies. Foils on the outside of foam are good for very high frequencies, because they shift it down to foamy frequencies.
Cheapest material you're gonna find for general "life" sound is acoustic ceiling tile.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2539469
That mix is extremely thin as anything but an initial penetrating sealer coat, and needs to dry thoroughly before recoating or trapped solvents will cause uneven drying and possibly bubbling. 10% is about the maximum you can safely thin something like varnish or oil based paint without compromising the cured film strength of the coating...there's better products to improve flow and leveling an open time like Penetrol.
Oil based varnish is a perfectly acceptable exterior finish, it's used on boats all the time and can be kept in good condition with a light sanding and recoat every 12-15 months or so in all but the most extreme heat/ sun exposure.
t. did marine varnish on yachts for years

You can replace existing outlets with GFCI outlets. You can't replace a switch with one unless you run a neutral.

posts.name: Kevin Van Dam
posts.com:
>>2531044
What anon said. If there’s already an outlet there, you will be cool. An outlet needs 2 wires for power, the live and neutral, and any outlet you will replace has those 2 going to it. But a switch only has one wire coming in, the live. The neutral is connected straight to the light or whatever like anon’s pic. You only have part of the circuit going through the switch, so you can’t just replace a switch with an outlet without getting the neutral wire to it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2531044
You typically don't just throw a bunch of GFCI outlets everywhere. Outlets are usually ran in a series from a breaker at your panel. And you put them in to trip those rather than the breaker at the panel. Our bathroom sockets run from the panel, to the second bathroom, and feed over to the master bathroom; so the second bathroom gets the GFCI. Yours is the last in the chain because you don't have a second set of wires feeding over to anywhere else.

Find the first socket in the series for that breaker, put a GFCI outlet on it, then put a regular socket where you've put this one.

posts.com:
>>2527235
Lots of kids end up in humanities literally just because math and science are so poorly taught in high school. By the time they are in high school, most kids dislike math and science because they think they're too hard. They aren't hard, they've just been failed in one or more topics. Failing is a normal part of learning any subject, but schools don't give kids time to go back and retry things they didn't master the first time. So kids just accept that they "don't know" x subject and have to leave it at that because it's time to move on. Teachers have curriculum goals that they have to meet so that when standardized testing rolls around, enough kids can give enough right answers to keep the school funded.

Subjects like language arts and history are a lot harder to fail, because there's less to get wrong, so kids end up thinking these subjects are the only things they are "good" at. These subjects are often tested with essays read by human proctors, which are way more forgiving than multiple choice math and science.

When it comes time to graduate high school, theres enormous pressure on kids to go to college and pick a major. They, logically, want to pick a major they are likely to succeed at, so using their limited window into education and job training, they arrive at the conclusion that they have to take humanities.

In an ideal world, kids would learn hard subjects at their own pace, and take as much time to master subjects as they need. For many reasons this is extremely impractical for a system that needs to educate thousands of kids per county, but that's the result you get: kids who just think STEM isnt for them.

Some advice from me:
1. You need to become a man and seperate yourself from your mother
2. Which means you need to get a job and move out from your mother to become independant
3. Think about what you wanna do, just the direction and find a small or medium sized company that gives you something like an apprenticeship and can maybe even help you with your own appartment. Maybe you'll have to move or something.

If you want to repair shit like cars or boats, find a car, truck or agricultural machine shop.
If you want to get into building houses become mason, go into "civil engineering" as construction worker, become a roofer. Just some examples

Plumber/HVAC is pretty much between those fields. You got electrical stuff, electronical stuff, lots of steel, iron and copper related stuff, bolts, screws - breddy much everything.

No matter what you do you can still go to college after some years of apprenticeship and become a technical engineer - in fact your practical experience will make you better than all other freshman.

Remote work is hard.
You either get paid almost nothing for being a telemarketer, or you are someone who is a senior programmer who works 80 hours a week.
Not anything in between.

You could also work for yourself trying to run some sort of internet store or ebay business or similar. But that takes huge amounts of work, is risky and money is really hit and miss.

FWIW, a family friend is a higher up programmer (like 20+ years in the industry) and rented out his house.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2527234
I have a polisci degree from a higher-end state school and ended up a licensed fire sprinklerfitter. It does happen, OP, but my circumstances were a lot different.

Construction is hard, man. Commercial even more so. I’ve only had Christmas Day off the past month. I make considerably more money than my friends/roommates (in my late 20s) but they have cushy WFM jobs that don’t require them to look like they just climbed out of a coal mine at the end of the day.

Expect to get yelled at. Expect to feel like an absolute incompetent idiot for at least the first two years. Expect to be so tired you pass out when you get home and sit down to take off your boots. I’m currently working towards my NICET II design cert which will hopefully get my ass in an office chair, because I can’t keep doing this.

I’d say go for residential plumbing, carpentry, low-voltage (fire alarm), or HVAC. The residential jobs I’ve done have all been laid back and the guys seemed to really know their shit and wanted their work to look good.

The appraiser was visibly upset, turns out that collectors value originality and patina over looks and what would have gone for upwards of $500K at auction if just left alone was now worth less than a typical soda can's five cent recycling value.

Also, the reason that can't pull tab was placed inside the can is because it wasn't the vastly superior tab design with the notches that let you twist off the sealing flap portion and stick it in a notch and use it as a spring to launch the pull ring part like a Frisbee into your friend's eye.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Anyone ever recondition or restore vintage chairs? Think I’m gonna try reupholstering the yellow one, and maybe just fabric painting the gray one.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Yes, I used to work in an upholstery shop.

Usually the hardest thing is patterning the old material. Imagine 50 year old vinyl, that's never been removed, etc. Not only does it have 'memory' of the chair shape, but it has deformed at the stress points. Making a replacement involves some guesswork.

If you redo the foam, that will be the most expensive thing. I've seen plenty of old chairs where the foam has deteriorated so that it's brittle/crumbly, and the lot of it needs replaced.

If you have any specific questions, it can't hurt to ask. I also lurk in the sewing thread, if there is one.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I pretty much soak small items in a sink of hot water and washing powder, stiring or 'agitating' occasionally. Squeeze out and rinse with cold water one or two times. It's not perfect but low enough effort with only a sink, draining board and kettle to use.
Drying I just squeeze out water then line everthing up on a wooden rack, placed infront of a radiator in a 'wet' room.

Heavily soiled items are soaked in hot water and washing powder, then run through a washing machine as usual.

Most of the time I avoid handwashing larger items like towels, trousers and heavy tops as they're much harder to squeeze and take days to dry. I've even tried twisting them 'roung a tree - it works, but not well enough.

This winter has been pretty bad for washing, to be honest.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Dye and scent free detergent
>wash all darks
>wash all lights
>shirts in dryer for 10m warm
>pants in dryer for 10m warm
>hang shirts damp
>hang pants damp
>all the way dry stuff in dryer hot 120m (underwear socks towels)
>walk away

Hanging prevents shrinkage, batch hanging skirts and pants separate allows for consistent work flow. Separating before drying prevents mistakes and is easier outside the dryer. There is a slight time loss if you have light shirts before the first dryer cycle, but it's small compared to the effort saved by isolating tasks.

posts.com:
When that initial covid toilet paper thing happened, I got some Brondell bidet off Amazon. It was about $30 then. It's the bolt on kind, where you take the seat off to install it.
Works pretty well, I like it. Only two settings: spray your ass, and self-clean. That was more important to me than multiple nozzles, multiple water input/temp control, etc.

There's a "splatter shield" in front of the nozzle, and the nozzle only extends when you're using it. Uses the line pressure to extend, when you cut the water a return spring pulls it back up. The self-flush/clean does a good job, it's been low-maintenance.

Didn't use the toilet supply line, I ran off the sink's hot water. So there will be an initial room temp spray, then HOT lol. I did get toilet seat bump stops that are slightly taller (maybe 1/4"?) so I don't stress the seat when I'm sitting on it.

If the city water is turned off (depressurized) then the poop water could be siphoned back into the city water system, leading to contamination. Certain weird cases such as fire hydrant use can also cause negative pressure in the pipes in your home.
You'll find that a lot of the codes, including the electrical and building codes, have to do with addressing edge cases where several unusual fault states are present at the same time.
>>2531683
I'm not that anon, but there are several code sections like Universal Plumbing Code section 603 which talk about back flow preventers. IDK if it's applicable to bidet hoses, but its an oversight if they haven't addressed it specifically in the code. The exact same mechanism of action that could lead to contamination from a pull down sprayer in a commercial sink or a garden hose could be found in these bidet hoses.

posts.com:
2 Professional solutions that are probably not what OP is looking for because they are expensive:
-Get a "tap" for bathing tubes or showers next to your toilet and connect it with a very small shower head (some hundred bucks for the tap, some hundreds for the work and pipes, tiles and shit need to be removed and made new)
-Get a toilet with integrated ass-shower (several thousand bucks)

My /diy/-advice: Get 2 multi-angle-valves where your wash basin is. It is usually near the toilet. The Kinda valves that you put an additional outlet for washing machines. Then do some /diy/ plumbing (you could even use a garden hose) from the 2 valves down and pull them next to your toilet. Then connect them with 2 1/2" "connector panels" (one for warm, one for cold) that you fix on the wall (you can use the tile joint so you don't have to drill into the tiles. Enclose the /diy/ piping with cheap drywall shit and put picture related on the connector panels.

That would be the /diy/ way of making your own ass shower.

If your landlord don't like it you can tear it apart and none of the tiles will be damaged. If the piping leaks you can just turn it off at the angle valves.

You have two options here. I'm a professional mechanic and small gas engines are also something I do on the side.

Electric chain saws are shit. They just are. Unless you're prepared to be able to split that battery pack open when the cells don't hold any more power then forget it. Corded? Get real.

Chainsaws? Stihl. I've seen a Husqvarna weed Wacker burn out in a summer, one per year according to my roommate. I pulled it all apart, 30psi. compression. They need 90 on the spec sheet just to fire. Poulan, Craftsman, anything else, forget it. Stihl holds value and is one of the best saws out there. Just take care of it like you would a Lambo. You'll really be in for a good time then.

With regard to oil mixing, Walmart has bottles with all kinds of ratio measurements near the outdoor/sports section near the marine 2 cycle oil. May be some near the regular PMV oil as well. Take care now.

posts.name: Kevin Van Dam
posts.com:
>>2531754
He’s reciting second hand some myth from an old man who repairs small engines and has no idea what he’s talking about. Pretty sure alcohol burns cooler than gasoline, and ethanol is alcohol.

The reason people like to run 0% ethanol
like Rec 90 or overpriced TrueFuel is because ethanol degrades fairly quick and regular E10 gas will clog up those tiny carbs when you let it sit in there for weeks in between use. I’ve also heard it’s not good for some older style fuel lines, the rubber and plastic, but any engine made in the past few decades is designed to be run on gas with minimum 10% ethanol.

>>2504840
i'm an arborist by profession.
Even modern high quality chains break from time to time. either from misuse, accident or material fault. on average a chain snaps on me every one to two years. luckily modern chainsaws have a chain catcher under the clutch so even when a chain should snap it will immediately arrest on the catcher as it leaves the bar on the underside and be stopped at the catcher immediately - if you are lucky - just dropping down from the catcher harmlessly or slapping the hand guard on the rear grip where it will lose its momentum.
in the worst of cases one of the chain links will get caught and the rest of the chain will come whipping around on the underside of the bar - miss the hand guard and slap the underside of your rear arm, upper leg or your hip if you are holding the saw sideways.
in any case its going to be like a 35mph whip with teeth but it wont keep running and actually be pulled through your flesh as it hits you. wounds from this should be superficial due to the chain loosing most of its energy on the catch.

should you ever pick up a saw with this safety feature missing or damaged, do not use it!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2523532
>that larger pool of opportunities might seem to make doing it more probable
yes that is literally how statistics work, if you have a p chance of not cutting your finger off and n number of opportunities to cut your finger off then the probability that in your life you cut your finger off is p^n. This function approaches 0 and for a sufficiently large n always ends with you cutting your finger off. Having a larger number of times where you don't cut a finger off is not going to undo the one time it does happen.

>>2505565
Jack safety is easy with cribbing as you go, I use my forklift jack to raise shipping containers when I add one to my shop (whose foundation is suitably large I-beams) and to put pipe rollers beneath. I also use classic Simplex mechanical jacks, the best being an early 1900s 329 telephone pole jack they still manufacture today. The chain grab is insanely handy:

https://www.ebay.com/itm/155277421886

6x6, 4x4, 2x4 and misc flat steel stacked as I go mean the jack could vanish and I'd be in no danger.

Wood cribbing has excellent traction on steel (the reason for placing a board between forklift forks and milling machine rams when lifting) and doesn't crush. The Air Force stores Mark 84s on wood dunnage in the field.

posts.name: Kevin Van Dam
posts.com:
This thread went on way too long without mentioning pic related.

Most other tools have one way to fuck you up. The pole saw will fuck you up in many ways.

1) It’s a heavy saw on the end of a long pole, puts you on the end of a really long lever mechanism, so you get up on a ladder and reach for a branch off to the side and lose your balance and take a fall

2) If you remain on the ladder from #1 and get the saw on top of that branch, you cut through it and as soon as you get through the branch, the heavy end of that sharpened chain comes falling down from the tree

3) You cut a big branch at the wrong angle and get the blade wedged in there, now you have a half cut tree limb and a piece of equipment precariously hanging until something gives

4) You aint got time to trim little branches all day, and it’s a chainsaw so you can go through a limb just as thick as the bar on the saw, and you end up dropping 1/4 of a large tree from 15ft above you right onto your dome.

#4 almost got me. I actually cut most of the smaller branches off and then chopped off a log like 6” wide and 3’-4’ long, forgetting how heavy wet wood like that is. The corner of the log clocked me in the forehead.

Recognize exist for people who don't understand how you get Kickback from the solely getting pinched on the back side of the cut.

>>2539750
In some cases like kitchens where grease is an issue sanding alone isn't enough to prep for recoating.
TSP acts both as a cleaner/ degreaser and also etches and softens existing paint for maximum adhesion/bonding when you paint within the proper time frame after using it.
You may not *need* to do it with every situation but it's good insurance and saves lots of time where textures and grooves and such might trap and hide greasy/glossy spots that cause problems.

>>2539791
PVA primer is for brand new unpainted drywall, not general purpose painting.
Also unless you are in the desert, doing primer + 2 topcoats in the space of 1.5- 2.5 hrs is a recipe for all kinds of problems from bubbles to uneven sheen to peeling the underlying coats as you roll and/or brush out over them.
Your time management proposal of waiting overnight after washing is stupid ; if anything you prime one day and let it dry overnight and if conditions are right you * might* be able to push two coats the next day, but not 1-2 hours apart unless there's zero humidity and it's warm AF and you're spraying.

You're also wrong about sanding in between- it may not be necessary 100% of the time and there's better things than sandpaper to do it with, but scuffing between coats and knocking down dust tits and gloss isn't just for cars and isn't just a meme.
You have no fucking clue what you're talking about.

I need to select a battery powered electric torque driver with consistent results, will be using torque settings in the 2 to 4 Nm range. The ones I can find are all corded, you guys have a recommendation for me?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2538189
You don't see many battery powered options for two reasons:
1. Torque delivered will vary depending on battery charge level.
2. The electronic controls required to deliver precise amounts of torque (in pretty much any given range) from a motor, generally speaking, will not fit in the handle of a screw gun.
Some of the lesser ones use electric speed control but fall back to mechanical torque control mechanisms. (e.g., a clutch like on a drill.) That's why they constantly have to be calibrated (clutch wear) and it's why the good ones all have external control, are completely electronic, self-calibrate, and cost upwards of $5K.
Having said all that, I did just find this:
https://capritools.com/shop/precision-digital-torque-screwdriver/
And they do offer a version which falls just about in your range. Not sure how precise/reliable it is.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2531818
I'd say your thought is on the right track, but this ain't it chief.
Gravity forcing the heavier cold air rushing out and get replaced with room-temp air that then needs to be cooled when opening and closing a side-operated door, and the seal having to fight the same cold air even when closed, should in theory make normal side-operated fridges much less energy efficient than top-operated ones, especially with frequent use. This assuming everything else about the two units being equal, indeed we see this in freezers where top-operated 'chest' freezers are common and consistently more energy efficient than their side-operated counterparts.

But things aren't always equal, and electric coolers have problems. First the simple inconvenience factor from having to stack things on top of each other instead of putting them on a shelf. Then theres that coolers have very very varying build quality, even more so than mini fridges which are already a mixed bag compared to standard fridges, chances of getting one with shit insulation is high. Coolers also generally have weaker compressors cause they're made for portability (and some have peltiers which are even worse), so on a hot day (or just a normal day if you live somewhere fairly warm) you might not be able to get down to fridge temps.
If you want anything half-decent, you're going to be spending at least $300 for a 45L/48 quarts cooler, maybe $400, and best case scenario the energy savings will make it break-even in 10 years, provided it doesn't shit itself at the 5 year mark.

You're probably better off spraypainting your existing fridge grey and not opening it as often.

>>2531818
Those portable fridge are shit, just vinyl or paint the old one
>Also, feel free to use this thread as a general discussion about lessening your energy bill. Do have any advice about energy saving practices?
Insulate your house, this is the most important one passive improvements would always be better than active ones, if you are renting and you are in a shit situation, food plastic wrap can be used to make a shitty but working 2 chamber in your windows, it would look bad, but it works.
Even a single solar panel would compensate your fridge consumption and whatever else is the base consumption on your house , so look into getting one if possible, in a roof balcony or a wall looking to the south would be enough. If your base consumption is higher than your fridge consumption plus 100w (all shut down but the essentials) look what may be wrong with it. People usually install thinking into the maximum consumption, or even the median, but if you are trying to save just look into your base consumption, and also if you are renting it would be easy to just take it with you when you leave. Remember that you also need an inverter.
If you don't have humidity problems, every time you take a shower, bath, clean your hands with hot water, close the drain until the water has gotten cold. That hot water would be wasted down the drain, in this way you get back the warm to your apartment.
A heat pump will be always better than a resistive heater. For people renting consider a portable AC, the kind with two tubes is pretty efficient and you can take it with you when the lease ends or just sell it.
In humid climates a dehumidifier may provide more comfort at lower power consumption than other options.

look up basic stick framing. buy 1000$ worth of 8' 2x4's. Build tiny cabin, super easy, side with 3/4 inch plywood. Wrap in tyvek house wrap. add used door and add a window or two. Its super easy. For roof just do leanto with rubber, tin, or shingles. Super easy. Wont be great and wont last for 100 years (might if you take really good care of it) but its a great starter cabin. also put it on cement blocks. There you go, easy as pie. This is how i built my gardenshed/sauna.
People nowadays assume everything is harder and more complex than it really is. Ultimately we are the same creatures that used to live out of a cave. Now we just live in wooden caves. You can do this. Good luck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2538071
>Could I build a driveway with pipes running through it that connect to the top of my sewer pipe?
No. Just no.
Why?
No city would allow you to connect to the sewer system like this.
The sewer isn't pressurized, there's no way to get even circulation.
Sewer gas is potentially explosive.
During storms or floods your pipe system would flood with sewage.
If this worked the streets wouldn't ice over because the sewers would keep them warm. However the streets DO ice over. Meaning that there's not enough heat to warm up the concrete above and then melt the ice/snow.

>>2538078
Retard, if you're going to add a boiler you could just run radiant snowmelt tubing under the driveway and use the boiler to heat it.

Driveway snowmelt requires either a boiler system with radiant tubes under the driveway or an electric heater mat under the driveway.

>>2509786
There were lots of small improvements made in the 1930s and 1940s when they were more widely used. Unfortunately it seems like most of the knowledge is spread out among communities that don't talk to each other.
For example, there are a few people in Sweden who drive gasifier-fueled cars, and every single one of them use a "stacked pancakes" fabric filter (a large "sock" that is tied off around wireframe discs; used to be canvas cloth in the 1940s, nowadays it's fibreglass). I've never seen for example Americans use fabric filters. Burgers all seem to use the Wayne Keith design, but the details are a trade secret and nobody outside of the US has heard of it.
The basics should be the same though, and there are some obvious things like insulating the hearth (firebox?) and using a heat exchanger for the air intake that I would do.
Another thing would be to convert a modern electric hybrid car. The pros and cons of a gasifier and a battery vehicle means they would complement each other pretty well.

Cyclones filter out particles; they are heavier than the gas and get flung to the outer wall and fall down. The intended use is that they catch most of what comes out so that the filters clog up less often.
Dealing with tar is mostly done, from what I've seen, by minimizing production (right fuel, right temperature) and cooling the gas before it reaches the engine.

I've researched a ton on steam engines, but I've slowly realized there are too many reasons gas engines are superior. Steam engines become very complicated when trying to make them competitive. Most people aren't going to mess with steam boilers (regardless of whether the design is safe), while steam generators require precise controls. Most burner designs have the flame quenched by the boiler/generator with a lot of unburnt fuel appearing as smoke. Ideally, only the exhaust should make contact with the boiler/generator. COGAS (Combined Gas and Steam) engines actually uses the exhaust of a gas turbines to heat a boiler and are among the most efficient combustion engines out there. Going back to using turbines for wood, you'd also use a separator like you would for wood gasifiers, the only difference is all the heat is concentrated in one operation for a higher thermal efficiency.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2517210
>What do you mean by efficiency here?
Power vs. fuel consumption

>having a cold gas at the start of the cycle increases the difference in temperature and therefore pressure.
Having a colder temperature would increase the efficiency of the Carnot cycle if delta T remains constant. However, delta T is purely a function of the amount of fuel burnt, heat capacity, and heat lost to the surroundings. A slower burn is going to lose more heat to the surroundings and an incomplete burn means less fuel burnt. In practice, a slower burn is also going to have less room to expand, and less work will be recovered from it, but a Carnot engine doesn't have any notion of a stroke or expansion ratio.

>>2504527
I wonder how hard it would be to make methanol from wood or coal syngas. You can convert gasoline engines to methanol rather easily.

There's a 99.8% selective methanol synthesis from carbon monoxide and hydrogen with a copper and zinc oxides catalyst at engine cylinder pressures (750~1500 PSI) and kitchen oven temperatures (250C / 500F). It can also work with carbon dioxide and hydrogen or carbon monoxide and water, since CO2 and H2O are intermediates in the process.

Apart from methanol being a gasoline substitute, there's also a simple dehydration reaction with solid acid catalysts (such as gamma alumina) at the same temperature and pressure conditions to produce dimethyl ether. DME has very similar handling characteristics to propane, and is non-toxic and non-corrosive and can be burned for heating and cooking, but also works well in diesel engines (with some conversion required, obviously).

These processes seem like they should be simple enough for small factories run by an individual or small team. Not too much harder than the combination of wood gas conversions and moonshining, and you get fuels that can be handled, stored, sold, and generally used for all the same things as today's standard fuels. You can make them from fire wood in the countryside, coal in coal country, and if solar panels keep getting cheaper, eventually from electrolysis hydrogen and CO2 from chemical capture methods or biomass (you can still get CO2 out of biomass you can't easily burn properly for energy).

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2518142
The toxicity of methanol isn't that much worse than gasoline. Its reputation for toxicity is mainly from people mistaking it for ethanol and drinking it with enthusiasm. DME is basically non-toxic.

Butanol is attractive in several ways (including its gasoline-like energy density), but since it's produced by fermentation, it's a much more finicky, picky process. You probably can't make it from coal or electrolysis hydrogen, except by complex synthesis no easier than gasoline. Furthermore, the fermentation process only works on cellulose, it'll do little to nothing with lignin, which is a major component of wood.

Not him, but offshore drilling rigs, fracking rigs, and refineries are all complex operations dependent on sophisticated industry and the cooperation of many people. In a breakdown of social order, they could easily cease operation.

Cutting firewood and strip-mining coal are relatively unsophisticated by comparison, and as a regular average dumbass, you can probably participate in them in an energy crisis. Even mining coal with a pick and a shovel is surprisingly productive, probably better than cutting firewood with a chainsaw and a hydraulic splitter. And because we've largely moved on from firewood, there's a lot of energy saved up in the trees we haven't cared to cut down. American industry ran largely on firewood through most of the industrial revolution, because of those vast pre-industrial forests, and they have recovered quite well since we switched to oil and coal.

We're pretty careless with spending energy because it's so cheap, but if things go to shit, we've got to at least be able to keep the farms running, and the trains and riverboats, and short-haul trucking to get goods into the stores. Wood and coal can do that, with far from ideal social organization, if we're smart about it.

>>2518526
>Can we get a description of what's happening here?
Sure. I guess I should add some reference number. Essentially there are 3 circuits:
- the air circuit (hatched) that cools the mantle before being diluted with exhaust and then is fed into the reactor (bottom right)
- the wood gas circuit from the reactor going through tar absorbers and filter before going to the gas turbine, while being cooled by water
- the water circuit that goes in opposite direction to the wood gas circuit, picking up heat throughout the path, before being superheated in the spiral at the bottom of the reactor and then powers a steam turbine.

Lots of details (condencer, recuperator, waste extraction etc) are missing but I hope those are obvious anyway.
Wood in the first tar absorber is fed to the reactor through the yellow square chute at intervals, thus recycling the tar.

Airlocks aren't that complicated, you just need two doors.

>put fuel in loading chamber
>close outer door
>open inner door
>fuel falls into combustion chamber
>close inner door

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2523152
The amount of energy it would require to run a wood chipper off your engine would almost certainly negate any advantage you'd get out of the setup. I think the most efficient way to to this would be to somehow automate or at least greatly simplify the process of loading entire logs into the combustion chamber.

As for wood pellets, a lot of the reason for their efficiency advantages don't apply in a gasifier. They're more efficient than a regular wood stove because they burn using a forced convection system, and as a result of the forced convection and their high density they burn at a much higher temperature than regular wood. Forced convection isn't possible in a gasifier and the heat of the reaction doesn't matter much when the process you're using relies on further chemical reactions downstream of the gasifier.

I also question if charcoal in a gasifier is a good idea. The process of making charcoal is essentially the same thing as what's happening in a gasifier, except by separating those processes you'd be losing out on the stream of volatile exhaust gases that come out of the charcoal and relying solely on the carbon monoxide to fuel your car. Using charcoal you're throwing away a good portion of the energy of the wood, and once again the advantage of a higher temperature burn doesn't benefit a gasifier like it would in a furnace.

Here in Sweden we explicitly used normal firewood. The government set standards saying that only specially treated birch was acceptable for cars (called bilved, "car firewood"), but in my parts of the country (very rural, even today if you don't work in forestry or paper manufacturing, you're a farmer) people were just using the exact same firewood they stockpiled for heat in winter, and by all accounts it worked just fine. Some of the wood gas converted cars stayed like that for decades, until the government got stricter about what you were allowed to drive on the road. Even when I was growing up in the 90s my neighbor still had an old wood-gas tractor. He never used it because he also had a modern diesel tractor, but it still ran. He drove it into town for the autumn market festival to show it off a few times. Using firewood probably produces more exhaust or ash than the bilved, because pine doesn't burn as well as birch in the first place, but I don't think that matters too much. Pine firewood is significantly cheaper than birch, let alone birch put through whatever treatment the government wanted people to do.

Here in Norway, Alder was the preferred kind of firewood for wood gas generators. Pine and connifer have a lot of resin that can cause tiny explosions that throw sparks everywhere, but is perfectly find in a closed oven.

Other than drying, I have no idea what kind of treatment they had for birch.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2530812
I think I understand what you meant now.
Filtering takes place in several steps. The first one (above the gas generator) catches tar and some particles in the tar. Once the wood in the tar absorber is fully loaded, it is sent down the chute (yellow square) into the gas generator. The filter is rotated so right side wood is turned to the left side and more wood is added. This lock means you avoid CO poisoning.
The next filter is more tar filtering by wood chips, as shown in >>2504529. You could move that to the gas generator too.

The third filter is teh cyclone filter. And I guess you are concerned about carbon rich particles removed here. I would expect most of this to be ash particles rather than carbon rich particles. I don't know how you can separate these. Just feeding it all bak into the gasifier means you will have a lot of ash circulating.

posts.name: Turbro
posts.com:
>>2530831
Well your design is certainly more efficient than mine if paired with an Otto or Diesel engine. It could perhaps be simpler, lighter, and even more efficient if the engine was the detonating Quasiturbine type and the steam engine were replaced with pre-heated air. The EGR is potentially interesting if you are using the 2 CO2 + heat -> 2 CO + O2 reaction to feed + cool the gasifier, and provide some suction at the exhaust. However, the biggest downfall is what to do with the carbon particles (especially if you are feeding in pressurized exhaust).

posts.name: Turbro
posts.com:
>>2531534
>no energy to be obtained by burning carbonates.
CaCO3 -> CO2 + CaO (quicklime) would turn some of the heat into expansive energy (work). Quicklime is useful for many industrial applications.

>the gasifier operates at high temperatures
Two potential issues. First, there's a water coil cooling the bottom of the gasifier. Next, the CO2 + C -> 2 CO reaction is going to provide some cooling and expand the recirculated exhaust (taking back what I said earlier). A turbocharger could recover the work, but then it's basically my design with EGR and a high compression engine. The steam engine could be replaced with water injection before the turbine, and a condenser to pre-heat the intake and recover the water with extra for drinking and irrigation.

posts.name: Turbro

>>2532738
Replace combustor with a high compression engine, and it might be worth the otherwise pointless gasification stage.

>>2532811
>The gasifiers used on cars and buses during WWII are shown with coolers, also thee the first few images in this thread.
The designers were probably worried about the volumetric energy density of the gas, but all that goes out the window when you can put a bigger compressor to compensate.

>Would cooling really be a major problem?
The soot isn't going to damage anything as long as the engine is hot enough to avoid excessive deposition there, and it would actually lubricate if the engine was still cool enough to allow a thin layer of soot to form. (If we could do away with splash lubrication in an engine, that would probably be a significant gain.) However, the efficiency will go down if soot deposits are excessive anywhere in the system, which will require a cleanout as >>2532826 mentions.

Inappropriate cooling has plagued engine building since steam, where the flame was in thermal contact with the boiler in older designs, then again with non-regenerative cooling in IC piston engines which continues to this day.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2539799
Autobody sheet metal? Probably ask for a conformity certificate to check what steel grade it is, most likely you'll find a galvanized mild steel which is not the best idea. Check the stock you gonna buy with a magnet, if it sticks, that's not a proper austenitic stainless stuff. There are some types of highly alloyed steel with high chromium content that might be considered corrosion-resistant and marketed as such, but they are not true food grade inox.

Also, if you are going to weld these, you absolutely must check the material of the filler rod to be of required steel grade(s). You also need to clean your stainless welds with a stainless brush that has not been used for mild steels, and chemically passivate ("pickle") the welds with a special acid paste to remove residual oxidation and return the inox steel to its normal non-reactive state.

Also LMGTFY: https://www.ruokavirasto.fi/en/foodstuffs/food-sector/packages-and-other-food-contact-materials/question-and-answers/metals-and-alloys/

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2539457
Why do you imagine you want to power tools from your car? What is is you want to do? BE SPECIFIC.

I have inverters, corded tools, cordless tools and pneumatic tools. I rarely use inverters except to charge the cordless tool batteries which the small inverters do well. I use them more often during power outages to power my router and charge my notebook etc. I use car cell phone chargers hooked to spare batteries for my phones.

Larger and small inverters work but are a hassle because the engine must be running. I own them for backup rather than regular use and consider there to be no point in buying them to run tools. I got mine used for next to nothing.

Just buy cordless tools. They're amply effective as proven on many jobsites. There is nothing new to invent in this respect. If you have work to do have the sense to choose the most effective tools for the task. My corded tools stay in my workshops for heavy use (where the lack of battery bulk is also an advantage). I have pneumatics but haven't used them in several years despite using tools all the time (mechanic, hardcore DIYer). I even have CO2 tanks which can briefly power pneumatic tools but I use those for portable tire inflation and blowguns now and then.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2538915
If you need to turn objects as large as a spread hand you should look for a lathe that weighs as much as a young calf.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2538915
There are many caveats to what you want, but generally speaking,
>lightweight
>small
>cheap
>high precision
>can work any regular materials
is an impossible recipe. You can get small, lightweight lathes that can work up to 2" steel at most (because they don't have torque and rigidity at low rpm) and aren't precise for cheap. You can get small, lightweight precision lathes designed for extremely small parts and/or soft metals, which are usually quite expensive even used, maybe you can get one at $1k if it's really old and worn out, $2k for a more decent one. Or you can buy a big fucking two-ton lathe used for $2k which will possibly do good precision on steel up to 10-15" as well as just about anything else. If you're strapped for space, there are smaller 1-ton lathes that usually don't have much length but can still do 10" steel reasonably well.
The main caveat is that you can always grind things down to high precision even on a shittier lathe, but you'd have to know what you're doing if you want to go this way, and you'd need to get a grinding attachment for the particular lathe.

It's not terribly difficult to move serious machine tools without a rigger but your money at this point would be best spend taking a machining class (which if you volunteer to help out generally gets you machine tool access). Poking about without training can work but not very well or very fast. Training is worth it.

Machining is not cheap if making anything to better than potato tolerances. You can hunt all you want but that particular problem is not a solved one. Better to save, buy a home or rent one with a garage, then assemble your home machine shop. Do this in an area zoned agriculture (if Burger) and you can make a quite serviceable shop from one or more 40' High Cube shipping containers which are easy to dehumidify so I did. It's not beautiful so I don't bother posting it because spergtards but there are many industrial examples.

French cleat thread.

I've bought a table saw to get into french cleats.
Any advice?
What thickness should I be going for?

What have you guys made using french cleats?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2539707
Generally speaking, a shallower angle than shown is sufficient and makes for easier adjustment of things like cabinets that will be fixed in place with other fasteners and don't need that deep engagement.
A shallower angle is also less likely to break when made of solid wood.
Thickness depends on the item, its weight, how it stands off the wall and needs to have that hidden, etc.
For heavy items and cabinets 3/4" is about minimum, especially using solid cleat stock.
For stuff like pictures and medium sized mirrors thinner plywood works well too, just use quality stuff and make the angle deeper to help it lock in.

>What printer should I buy? [Last updated 2022-11-19]
Under 250 USD: kingroon KP3L, Sovol sv01, Creality Ender 3 (v2), Anycubic Mega S
Under 500 USD: Qidi X-One2, Creality CR-10, Anycubic Vyper, Prusa Mini
Under 1000 USD: Prusa i3, Bambu Labs X1
Over 1000 USD: e3d toolchanger, Ultimaker, Qidi X-CF Pro, Build your own Voron, Rat Rig, Prusa XL (lol enjoy the wait)
SLA: Anycubic Photon, Elegoo Mars 2+, Prusa SL1, Formlabs Form 3, Creality HALOT-ONE
Instead of buying a new printer, you could consider building your own: https://reprap.org/wiki/

https://google.com/

https://www.yeggi.com/
T*legr*m

>What CAD software should I use?
Variants of professional parametric CAD programs such as Solidworks (lol paying for software), Fusion360, Inventor, Onshape, TinkerCAD, and AutoCAD may be free depending on your profession, level of piracy and definition of ''free''.
Most anons use Fusion360, but some /g/oobers prefer OpenSCAD or FreeCAD. If you want to do mesh free-forming and modeling, Blender is alright. Also while not necessarily a design program, Meshmixer (free) can be extremely useful for tweaking models to print.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2538570
>For some reason I can't adjust wall thickness with prusaslicer.
Turn on Advanced settings.
Layers and Perimeters -> perimeter count
Advanced -> Perimeter and External Perimeter extrusion width
Wall thickness = perimeter count x extrusion width.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2538570
i find that cura has more control than prusaslicer does. the only thing i'm aware of that prusaslicer cannot do is changing flow for different operations (changing flow for infill, top surface, outer perimeters, etc) and tree supports.
you can absolutely change outer perimeter width. i print my outer walls thinner for more detail, and then inner walls thicker so they go down quicker. if you're pushing against the limit of your setup (15 mm2/s or whatever on an ender) then you'd want to be able to crank flow for the inner walls separately.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2538582
yeah but that's assuming a linear relationship with flowrate (or i'm assuming they're assuming one).
you can set all that on cura too, but you can also override the flow multiplier. so if your outer wall is printing at 10 mm2/s but your inner walls are going 20 mm2/s, you might be getting underextrusion on the inner walls.
instead of slowing down your speeds, you could just up the flow multiplier for the inner walls to compensate, and keep printing at the same speed.
or, you can selectively underextrude your supports so they come apart easier. yeah you can change wall width and shit, but you can also just push less plastic out and that makes it weaker too.

Tree supports tend to cut down on wasted material while also giving better results, because they use less material at the bottom and can be spaced pretty close together at the top.
Supports are sometimes just unavoidable for certain parts, but a good designer can avoid them completely. For example, all the Voron printed parts don't need support, there are just a few that have a break-away simple support piece built into the model.

>>2538743
what i would recommend doing (or rather what I did) is downloading stuff like a stock and looking at their step or f3d files. often times you don't get f3d files, most people export as steps, but f3d is the best because you can see the timeline.
then what you can do is drag through the timeline and see how they made the thing. like, they'll draw a shape, then extrude it. then put a chamfer on a vertex. then maybe draw a new shape and extrude that.
you can go through and tweak their steps and see how that impacts what happens. like, change the chamfer. change the shape that gets extruded. draw another shape, etc. this is also how i first "learned" programming. tearing up other people's source code and seeing what i could do to influence the end product. it's very intimidating to go from nothing to a full part, but if you look at the timeline and see how the person went from nothing to a stock, then you can develop that same type of thinking.
alternatively, just follow some tutorial series on youtube and buckle in for the long haul.

>>2538836
An ink jet mechanism has a tiny ink reservoir that is subject to a sharp, controlled pressure spike (as from a piezoelectric or thermal mechanism) that causes a tiny drop (of a precisely controlled size) of ink to shoot out of a tiny nozzle and onto the surface being printed. The print head contains a large number of these nozzles that print a swath of details in a single pass, with multiple sets of nozzles drawing from different ink supplies to produce different blends of colors.

i'm not disagreeing, but it doesn't mean they can't regulate it.
a concrete example is silencers in the US. maybe not exactly apples to apples but hopefully you get what i'm saying. you could turn out a silencer with a benchtop lathe.

the way the law works is that if you want to make a silencer, you pay 200$ and wait for your paperwork to be approved and then you can put one together. up until the past year or so, you could buy parts that slot together to make a suppressor. like a threaded tube of the correct dimensions, little metal cups of a certain size and shape, end caps of a certain size, etc. and then the regulatory agency responsible for handling firearms said that metal cups of a certain shape are suppressors, tubes of certain size are suppressors, etc. the parts are no longer "parts", it's a suppressor, and buying one is a felony. so all the websites that sold those parts fucking evaporated.

so all it would take, is saying that a glock barrel is a glock. and an ar15 trigger group is an ar15, and so on. you can still spin up a suppressor on a lathe, or an ar15 barrel on a lathe, but by regulating the trade of those parts, you crush the market, because it eliminates anyone who lacks the capacity to make the parts themselves.
so i don't think it would be logical to go after the printer itself, but i would not be stupified if it did happen. i could believe that things like tubes of a certain size, or springs of a certain size, might be regulated. like how certain chemicals are restricted because people make drugs or bombs or whatever out of them.
i don't support it, but i could believe it.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2538860
You can make a shotgun out of a few plumbing pipes and fittings, and those won't be restricted. Most of the parts needed for a 3D printer can be scavenged from a 2D printer, and those won't be restricted. Filament can be made or repurposed from all sorts of things, and plastic soda bottles won't be restricted.

>like how certain chemicals are restricted because people make drugs or bombs or whatever out of them.
The ones without ubiquitous uses may be restricted, but things like sugar, acetylene, and fuel oil are not.

These sorts of things are generally to prevent law-abiding normies from having things the government doesn't want them to have, but anyone actually interested in having them would generally find the actual barriers to acquiring them rather low. If people just ignore the dictate, the whole thing falls apart like Prohibition did, because those things can't actually be enforced effectively.

Basically you ink jet print after each layer. What's printed on top of a layer thinner than paper might as well be printed on the side so you get colored edges. Something like the starch support material would probably take the ink and then it's just a matter of lining a traditional ink jet up with the print. Increasing lidar use should put this in hobbyist hack soon if someone isn't already doing it for YouTube views.

>>2538997
The problem is that the X1 isn't in a niche. It's a general high-end printer that's going to cover 80 or 90% of the customers that would want a XL anyway just for the filament changing, enclosure (although the XL doesn't have a full enclosure), and speed. The XL is in a niche but not a good one. The tool changer will only be good for 3d printing heads, corexy in general isn't rigid enough for milling and it's not very economical for routing. Tool changing does work, but I've yet to see it offer a meaningful advantage over a filament changer when you're just 3d printing, and the tooling is probably going to be a breaking point. Based on DIY toolchanger designs I've seen the locking mechanism is usually good for high hundreds to low thousands of changes, which isn't a lot in the scheme of things. Prusa's a smart guy but I'm guessing there are some problems with the tool changer. And it's not like they're cheap assemblies.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2539020
>No purge
Tool changers still need a prime tower or purge to handle the excess extrusion on tool changing. Jubilee, an actual working tool changing printer in the wild, does the latter for example. There's no way Prusa isn't doing one or the other.

>easy use of multiple materials rather than just multiple colors
You can do this with a filament changer too, one of the main use cases is support filaments.

>use of multiple nozzle sizes or types in a single print
Useful in theory but in reality you'll be printing virtually all of your prints within the acceptable range of extrusion width. Plus current gen slicers are good enough at optimizing for extrusion values that it's not something you should be worrying about.

>Use of lasers for engraving/marking text
Arguably the only useful one, but you'd have to do a lot of laser engraving to make this more economical than just getting stuff made at a dedicated service. Plus if you plan to use a stronger laser it becomes a hazard which you need special enclosures and/or filters to handle safely.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2539210
i'd figure it's because black would absorb heat faster and radiate it away slower than white. dunno how significant it is, but that's what i'd initially figure.
bad overhangs happen when the material doesn't cool fast enough. you want to lay it down and it cool immediately.
if that is the problem, you could probably fix it by raising your minimum layer time, so the previous layer has time to cool before the getting a hot layer put on top.
however, those sagging overhangs are really only going to be obvious on smaller parts. if you were to print like, 8 of those cubes at the same time with the same settings, the overhangs would look better because they'd have plenty of time to cool off.
also, you might be able to lower the temperature a bit, because of it being black, and having better heat transfer. it might be insignificant though, maybe the pigment plays practically zero role in thermal conductivity.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2539213
That glass plate is only really better than a PEI mag sheet if you're using a completely flat/slick glass plate (not textured with anything) specifically for the very flat surface it provides your prints.

flexible build plates make printing 1 billion times more fun in my opinion. More more fighting with ultra stuck prints or slamming into the side of them with a fucking spatula or scraper. Just pull the plate of and pop that bitch of a print away from it with a little twist.
Even better, get two magnetic build plates so you can slap the second one on and start another print while you fuck with cleaning the first off.

Just get one (or two ideally) and never look back. The glass plate will be there for you if you need it for something specific. Otherwise magnetic plates are better in every way.

There are texture PEI magnetic plates as well. Some people really like that textured surface i guess because it hides imperfections of a shitty first layer and whatnot. I don't really use those but i can see the appeal

it's difficult for the home gamer.
what you'd want to do is look for a chemical compatibility chart, and pick a solvent that reacts poorly with those plastics.
methyl ethyl ketone is usually pretty good at dissolving most plastics, while still being reasonably accessible.
better ones are stuff like THF, cyclopentanone, cyclohexanone. you can't really get them as a home gamer. even MEK is pretty difficult to get nowadays. they're phasing out the powerful solvents because they give you cancer or liver damage or whatever. maybe you could use an ultrasonic cleaner. or just throw the nozzles away and buy new ones.
