>>2539493
I use the official 4.2.7 board and it works fine. 98% noise reduction. The fans are now the loudest thing on the machine.

I also have a CRTouch and it seems to work well, but you really want to have something like OctoPrint with the Bed Visualizer plugin, because it'll show you how level your bed is and tell you how many degrees to turn the knobs to improve the level. I've heard the CRTouch is more durable than the BLTouch, due to metal vs plastic parts.

If you don't replace the extruder clamp, at least have the all-metal kit on hand for when it does break. It's cheap. That's actually what's been most helpful to me: I bought every cheap replacement kit Creality offers and keep it on hand for when something fails. I found entire hot end kits for $12 and then a week after ordering it my stock hot end broke. There's also nothing more annoying than not being able to print because you don't have replacement PTFE tubing, or connectors, or nozzles. These are all cheap so it pays to have some extras lying around.

And your mileage may vary, but I found a glass bed to be unnecessary after getting my CRTouch working properly. The magnetic bed that can easily be pulled off and flexed to detach parts is way more user-friendly. Especially for materials like PETG that like to glue themselves to your bed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2539213
A bit fiddly/expensive to set up if your printer isn't made to use them stock, but for most purposes they offer the best print surface currently available. Either smooth or textured can print a variety of common materials without adhesive or release agent, and both with a glue stick will let you print anything short of superpolymers like PEI itself and weird stuff like Delrin. The main benefit isn't the surface itself, but the flexible sheet that lets you pop parts off with a flex. Having multiple sheets is also handy for keeping the printer running when you want to be productive, since you can immediately swap out a hot print with a clean sheet and start the next print. I would not seriously consider a printer without something similar.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2539215
>black would absorb heat faster and radiate it away slower than white.
The ability of a material to absorb heat relies on exactly the same properties as the ability to radiate heat. Dark colors heat up faster from sunlight, but they also cool down faster in darkness. In this case, the heat input is from conduction, which operates independently of color. The difference is probably due to the different filament composition from the different pigments used.

>>2539560
An all metal hotend needs really good cooling to keep the heatbreak cold enough for the filament to not melt in there. The way this is usually achieved is with a larger heatsink. The stock Mk8 heatsink is too small to dissipate enough heat. Same goes for the micro swiss as it's the same size as a Mk8. Yes, there's a bunch of improvements to the Mk8 design and material choices like the titanium heatbreak but it's just not enough. The constraint of fitting in the stock fan shroud of an ender 3 is too much. Heat creep issues are practically guaranteed at low flow rates.
The V6 doesn't have these issues because it gives zero fucks about where it's supposed to fit. It's made specifically as an all metal and was build from the ground up as such. It doesn't need fancy materials or manufacturing processes to work well. It is so simple even chinks get it right. 15$ for a clone and it's as good as the original stuff.

can you link me the model? I wanna have a look and see if i can figure out what is happening or figure a better way.

The Support W material is going to be terrible as a raft because it's meant to serve as a interface layer between the support and model that is *easy break away*.

It looks like the model might have complex enough geometry that it also can't get enough surface area on the build plate- which is why it might have failed that way like you said.
Possible solutions after that would be
1)Add more heat to the bed and pray for better adhesion
2) (probably should have been listed first) tell the slicer to add brims so that there is more surface area for adhesion. assuming the model geometry can support having brims on it
3) tell the model to fuck off and chop off a number of bottom layers so that it is actually flat enough to stick to the plate.

Alright.
I tried using the "auto-orient" option to find a better angle to print at, even if it was only a tiny tilt, but the best it could come up with still sucked chunks.

This model obviously (or at least seems to me) is meant to be printed on an SLA printer where it isn't really meant to touch the plate anyway and would be absolutely fucked to death with branching supports. If that wasn't what it was designed for then it probably wasn't designed for printing at all because it's just too organic and doesn't have a singular flat surface to be fucked with. Absolute nightmare for FDM. Supports don't work the same way as SLA and so you're still coin-tossing to get all the way through the print.

Pic related is after i chopped .85 off their asses to make it actually have surface area touching the plate. See the purple/blue surrounded by yellow? THAT is how the software tells you that it's actually touching the plate.
I would expect it to perform much better, HOWEVER, as you can see the two middle front feet still have *very little* touching and may still fail for the same reasons. Maybe chop more (using the in-slicer "Cut" option) if you want to give it even more of a chance.
THEN the next problem will be these idiots' dangling bell necklace things. These are overhang/support nightmares, but are at least smaller than the two suspended/round feet. The mouths are almost extreme too. Particularly the insides of the mouths.

The cheeks, hair details, and underbelly are challenges as well, but at least they are attached to another part of the model on the way up.

I'm not sure if you knew this was an absolute monster of an overhang/support torture test when you started it, but if you didn't know that then you do now. Complete insanity you got here methinks. Changing your temps up or down 5 degrees at a time and looking at differences can be a good way to approach it, then with that temp information you are more informed to change speeds (faster needs more heat, slower needs either less heat, more cooling, or both).

Consider testing with a "temp tower"


>>2539774
there's a youtuber called "dr d-flow" (i know, kinda cringe) that built a massive corexy printer. Your main issues are speed and being able to bring things to temperature. I think watching that video would be a good start for the questions you have and will eventually have.

Keep in mind that wood bends under weight, more bigger = more weight. It could be built strong enough to not bend/warp, but then it would need to move much slower otherwise break under the stress of moving heavy parts and deal with the vibrations. Things like that.

Then the heat problem keeping a build plate heated that is that large (depending on material). And also a chamber to hold that temperature in the print area without cooking the electronics.

You also probably don't want to print with tiny 1.75mm filament. that'd take eons for anything larger than a normal printer. You'll start printing with pellets.

good luck

>>2539795
raw PLA is a off-white fleshy color if i recall correctly.

Both black and white will have tons of pigments, but those pigments will give the material different thermal properties.
THERMALLY white should be easy to deal with, but it's usually white because there is some kind of titanium in it - very abrasive. If you print only in white you may find yourself replacing nozzles and tubes more frequently.

Not actually sure what thermal properties black would have because I don't print it much (haven't had any trouble with the polyterra that i use), but I assume it retains more heat and thus may be more of an issue dimensionally. In PLA though i would imagine the differences are mostly negligible. The real issue is tuning for a specific brand of filament. I wouldn't expect one blend of eleven herbs and spices to be the same as another brand's.

>>2539797
I used PETG. It's great for this sort of job, but can be sort of a pain in the ass to print because it likes to gum up and stick to the nozzle. But also they aint gotta be pretty, so maybe a good project to start using PETG with while you dial in settings for it.
PLA might do the job but i would expect it to sag and maybe tear after a while. Use lots of walls on your prints at 90 something % infill, and probably put more brackets closer together instead of doing long runs like mine. Every 10 inches maybe? They're thin brackets so they won't reduce your storage space too to add them. Another option would be to cut them out of plastic with a laser cutter like the repkord kits are, but i imagine you don't have a cutter if you're asking or considering purchasing theirs.

>>2539787
>keeping a build plate heated that is that large
Mains power heater mats. That shit is several times more powerful than anything running on 24V.
>a chamber to hold that temperature in the print area
If you're using plexiglass like all the reddit s01s and their vorons then yes.
I did the generic Lack table enclosure for my Ender 3 but used 2cm of extruded polystyrene instead of plexiglass. That shit holds 60C no problem with just the bed on. It gets warmer while printing. If you're making a big printer then extruded polystyrene enclosure would be a no brainer. You can even up the thickness to 5cm for more heat.
Also, that's another thing, the bed doesn't have to be the sole source of heat. Dedicated enclosure heaters are a thing.
>without cooking the electronics
At 60C+ an Ender 3 mainboard and an RPi survive no problems. But you should certainly mount that shit outside the enclosure if possible.
>You also probably don't want to print with tiny 1.75mm filament. that'd take eons for anything larger than a normal printer. You'll start printing with pellets.
This alone would be the dealbreaker for many. Though I don't see why you think printing is slow due to the filament. The Super Volcano is a thing. Yes, it's ridiculous, but it's made specifically for a ridiculously big printer.

>>2539917
probably yeah. if you need the walls that thin, you can do stuff like changing your infill overlap, or doing outer perimeters before inner.
lowering infill overlap reduces how strongly the infill will connect to the walls and makes your part less strong.
doing outer perimeters first means that the bulges from the infill wont propagate out into the surface layer, but it means that overhangs will sag more because those outer walls don't have the inner walls to brace themselves to during the print.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2540147
Chop out the individual mating areas an your CAD program, and then print those one at a time, adjust, print again until they are all good enough. No sense printing a whole enclosure every time to check four screws and a 6" (or whatever you kids use these days) ring, especially since you may need to try a few times to get it right.
Try to print each section in the same orientation that you think you will be printing it on the final design though, it does make a little bit of a difference. Not enough difference to fill your whole bed up with support material and an eight hour print, but see if you can get it close. Also wall count will be more important than infill here, I wouldn't go less than 3 walls if possible, but you can usually get away with 10-15% infill.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2540147
it's better to just print the face or print the side, or print a 45º cut through a corner if you need to check height. You can print down to about 2mm but I'd do like at least 10mm if you're for example printing the speaker holes and their mounts. It's not to hold the speakers it's to test the fit.

I was going to say don't do this with cheap filament, but over the size you're doing it probably won't matter. I've had some filament off 3-5% while others are perfect. but that's things under 100mm. Anyway you can prototype in cheap and eliminate material as above then do a similar test with your final filament e.g. one speaker hole minimal material one height corner to double check.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2540330
>have to be up on top of the thing changing spools too often
An MMU style unit could take care of switching between spools once one runs out.
5 3kg spools would give you plenty of filament to finish some pretty big prints. 5kg spools would be even better.
>Why bother when you can just load a hopper up with pellets, or a vacuum hose that delivers them from a 50gal barrel?
Pellets are difficult to source and you don't know what the fuck you're getting. Pellets are usually raw material but most filament manufacturers add a bit of other plastics or additives to the raw material to make it print better.
Also print quality with a pellet extruder would be quite bad. I imagine the flow wouldn't be that consistent, but most importantly you lack the ability to retract.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2541082
It's really easy to get started, and you'll run into annoying precision errors where shapes snap to nearby faces, making geometries not quite square, and causing all sorts of fuckery. May be best designing in metres and just telling your slicer that it's in mm. It also lacks any sort of history system, doing unities of shapes is kinda a pain, and extruding shapes on curved lines is broken half the time (and this is the only way to make something spherical). It's not at all parametric either, so I often find myself doing quick initial design in sketchup, before moving to OpenSCAD for autistic iterative adjustment of finer parameters. Transferring from sketchup to any other cad is also basically manual reconstruction of each and every measurement.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Particle board is probably too porous to use something like wood sealer or poly varnish unless you did like 10 coats of it. Wouldn't be a long term solution but since you said this is temporary that's not really a concern.

>>2518885
It was the combination of a few factors, but the biggest one is called "dot gain". Colors are made by mixing size and location of dots in 4 different colors. Sort of like how digital screens mix RGB pixels together to create colors.

When you print those dots, there are factors that can make the dots larger or smaller than intended. In this case the paper it was printed on absorbed the ink more, creating larger dots. There might have been other factors, I don't know.

The ad was already very dark and moody looking to begin with. I did one quick pre-press at a local printer, and it came out dark... I had them lighten it a bit and due to time/money had to send the files right away.

I was really proud of the ad. It was my first "big" print ad, and I also handled the photography and design from top to bottom. Like, I was planning on framing a copy of it lol.

I then advised to use an hypoxic fire protection. the datacenter was inside the hospital campus so they could route some nitrogen if they really wanted to. I am not sure though if hypoxic fire prevention is as reliable to prevent all fire scenarii.

https://www.weldpundit.com/vertical-welding/

Vert for vertical
Stove for downhill
A vert weld deeply penetrates & is naturally slower to lay with far more operator skill required.
A stove or downhill can be 'proper', but is quite likely to sit on top of the metal joint with negligible fusion. Not important in thin shit, very important in thick, load bearing members, right :)
A muppet can make a stove weld look good, even a gnarly vert is probably stronger than the parent metal around it.

I'm a machine operator at a large glass company which mostly provides machined blanks of very specialized glass types.
>company is headquartered in Europe so we use the metric system for consistency even though my plant is in the US
>few days after coming back from some time off, got an order to cut up a large casting on our wire saw
>these castings are big, several feet cubic in dimension and weigh about as much as your car
>saw uses a big, moving table about 3 feet off the ground, and since glass is non-magnetic we lift these big castings there with a vacuum-powered suction cup on the end of a gantry crane
>since the vacuum company is American, all the vacuum pads are rated in lbs
>biggest one is about 3 feet in diameter and is rated for about 5,000lbs

I don't have a good background to base any job recommendations off of. The tl;dr is I'm someone that can solve problems in an effective manner.
I work in a fabrication shop that is mainly B2B, we do literally anything and everything, and most of my job is telling my boss, and therefore the client, to fuck off, or figuring out how to do it on a bare bones budget.
I went to school for computer science. I enjoy programming, but not the industry at large, so I left so I could work with my hands again.
I do CNC/machining work, general fabrication. Basically I take a design document and work to make it a reality.
I have almost absolute freedom in my job, my boss trusts me to get the project made, and I have basically no micro managing as a result.
I love the problem solving aspect of this type of work, I love figuring out processes, building jigs, improving inefficiencies, but none of this was taught to me, it was always something I've been interested in since I was very young.
If you like problem solving, esp for someone else, fabrication work is good.
I enjoy problem solving too much to the point that I'll probably leave my job soon to pursue my own prospects. But I still love what I do.

>>2517916
Admitted a "do not resuscitate" woman to the floor I work on. She was choosing to not elect for surgery on her aortic aneurysm. She would die instantly if it were to dissect and without surgery it had a >50% chance per day of doing so.
She was pleasant, funny, and alert and oriented. The only thing we could really do was give her bp medication and wait for her family to arrive before she went home on hospice.
So I took her vitals and her blood pressure was high. Then I walked her through her admit questions which take about 15 minutes.
She asked if I would call her son as she wanted to see him before she passed and I said of course, wrote down his number, and intended to call him after our interview.
Ten to fifteen minutes later, as I was wrapping up, she became apprehensive. She started having stilted responses with a panicked look on her face. Then a few seconds later she stroked out/had a massive aortic dissection, and "died."

Called a doctor in, etc. who confirmed what had happened. Then I called the family and learned that her son had been waiting in the ER downstairs for half an hour d/t the front desk not knowing which room she was being moved to.

He came up and held her hand, facetimed family, etc. but she wasn't alive anymore in any meaningful way.

Her bp medicine wouldn't have been effective yet but I still regret not immediately reaching out to family and finding her son immediately.
There weren't any repercussions, and I don't know that I did anything necessarily wrong, but it certainly felt like I did and I think about it all the time.

>>2531891
A planer has the cutterhead on top for reducing the thickness of a board. A jointer has the cutterhead on the bottom to establish a flat and true surface. The thing about jointers/planers/tablesaws is that the length of board they can precisely cut is dependant on the length of the infeed table. These benchtop models have short infeed tables so I would face a board longer than a few feet on one.

Personally I'm just going to invest in a series of handplanes and figure them out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2535432
>I'm looking at getting a vacuum casting thing for making jewelry but I don't even think they make them in Australia so it's going to run me like 3k aud. Ideally I'd like to start selling the pieces I make but that's a ways off and I don't really know if a 3k gamble is worth it.

I built one myself and I shit you not it looks like this. Also in Australia. Not sure your use case exactly but I use mine for removing bubbles in resin during curing.

1) Get a oil vaccuum pump. Can be difficult to get hold of and you might get asked weird questions as apparently they are used in backyard drug manufacture. Mine cost around $600 maybe a few years ago.

2) find a plastic transparent thing like the dome in your pic.

3) Get a nice thick sheet of Perspex/Acrylic.

4) cut two concentric rings, and fill the gap between them with silicone sealant from bunnings, this is your seal for the plastic dome.

5) buy cheap bunnings air connectors and drill a hole in your thick perspex sheet to put the intake valve on, connect to your vacc pump

6) your seal goes on top of the perspex sheet, your 'stuff' goes on the perspex sheet inside your seal and your bowl goes over the top so you can see physical effects.

7) For added fun, put a gauge between your device and the vaccuum pump.

Boom, you got yourself a vaccuum chamber. Bunnings costs <$80. The most expensive part is the vacuum pump, i don't know how you can cheap out on that unless you find a good second hand one.

posts.com: I bought a new house. The previous home owner had 4 dogs and wasn't using filters in his hvac registers, they lived there 10 years, who knows how long with the dogs. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: If it's a one time thing just hire a company to do it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2537622
If you want a true, thorough duct cleaning and sanitizing then your best bet is to hire a professional. A properly done duct cleaning will run you $300-500, beware of the scammers who offer $99 duct cleanings. They either won't clean all of it or they'll start hitting you with extras right away. A good company will have either a truck mounted vac or a machine they bring in, uses air whips and brushes to get everything, and does neat patches when they're finished. Avoid the guys with a shop vac who do everything from the basement. Call your preferred HVAC company, they should be able to refer you. If not check Yelp and BBB ratings before you call someone.

There are places that will rent you a duct cleaning machine if you really want to do your own. You'll need to be able to cut an opening in your duct downstairs and patch it later. Be sure your HVAC system is off before you start otherwise it can suck in all the bullshit you stir up. I'd also replace the furnace filter when you're done and check it again after a week in case it fills up quicker from all the loose dust. If you get decent at it you could even do it as a side hustle.

Ok /diy/, I asked /g/ for advice and it turns out they're a bunch of posers who don't understand consumer electronics, so I'm coming to you for advice on picrel project I am ready to start soldering.

Basically, I need 5v DC, one analog video channel, and one audio channel. Please correct me if I'm wrong, but this means I need 4 wires because they can share ground? In that case, I have decided to use 3.5mm TRRS (because it is analog AV and meets size constraints), which I would like to be compatible with existing products also using this connector. The problem is that every major company seems to have implemented their own version. Worse, constant voltage destroys speakers, so I need to be very careful which pin is +5v.

>I would like to be able to plug in normal headphones (with mic or otherwise) to listen to the single channel of audio without destroying them, or at the very least without creating a short circuit.
>I would also like to be able to plug in my NTC CHIP which has its own TRRS that is laid out LRGV.
>I would also like to plug in a Samsung TV, which uses the layout VRLG.
>All else being equal, it feels right to me to have the sleeve be ground and tip be +5v.

Based on these goals, what do you think is the best layout? Also, will 5v destroy a headphone mic? Will an analog video signal do the same to a headphone speaker?

My project aside, which TRRS standard should rule them all?

posts.com:
You want to look into ordering quick release valves (QEVs), or modifying those bulky electronic sprinkler valves. After that is finding metal pipes and connectors, and also a tire valve repair kit to fill it. The simplest design is chamber -> valve -> barrel.
If you want multiple shots from a chamber you need a staging design, where a smaller chamber is filled and dispensed. QEVs can also be converted into machine guns, given you have a feeder for bbs or whatever.
You’ll need an air compressor, scuba tank, or a high pressure air pump to fill it. You can DIY those pumps, they’re fairly simple. Depending on your pressures you’ll either be soldering metal, or just glueing PVC together.
The absolutely monstrous designs mix propane and air into a compressed chamber, and seal it with a burst disk. Upon electronic ignition it fires with the force of a cannon.

>>2538214
alright. i have beginner lockpicking experience. here's how i learned the absolute basic bitch lowest tier knowledge

first: get some cheap padlocks, but not *too* cheap. brinks, master, those are both good. stay away from walmart hyper tough or dollar store locks, because those are deceptively easy to pick: usually you can jostle the bar holding the shackle in place because there's zero protections built in. master and brinks, to their credit, patched that exploit in most of their locks.

once you get your locks, take it very slow. start on the pin in the very rear of the lock. can you feel the pin? if you can, are you sure you're not feeling two? move the pick back and forth slightly until you can feel it better. once you're sure you have one, you can continue. if not, select a pin you might think works better. remember that slimmer and smaller is usually better on padlocks. don't try to single pin pick with a fuckin clover pick. just a hook is best.

then, apply some tension with a tension bar placed at the bottom of the keyway. a good idea for tensioning is what you might apply to a real key: since you're learning, lock and unlock your padlock with the key to figure out how much tension it takes. then, slowly move your pin up so you have a tactile and audible *click* and your tumbler moves a little bit. hold the lock up to your ear if you're a half-deaf retard like me. the important part is that you memorize not where the pin sets, but how it feels when it sets. it's very distinctive.

now that your first pin is set, you can move to the next: slowly and steadily move the next pin up. maintain pressure on the tumbler, try not to release it or apply a lot more. it's a balancing act, but it's easy to understand after a few tries.

if you can set the other 3-5 pins, you'll turn the tumbler. most cheap padlocks only have 4 non-security pins, so you won't need to worry about false sets from serrated or mushroom pins. 1/2

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2538672
2/2

now i'll tell you the easy ways to say "fuck this shit" and negro-hack locks.

>1
you see that wiggly pick there that has teeth about halfway down? that's called a rake pick. if you apply even tension to a shit padlock, you can literally RNG you pin sets and pop the cunt open by "raking" the lock. you shove it bacl and forth in the lock body like you're brushing your teeth. try not to hit the back of the lock or remove the pick all the way, that's inefficient and fucks you up. or if you like poking the lock's cervix...
>2
take your thinnest hook, drive it all the way back into the lock, and wiggle it in the direction of the lock's lettering (if any is present). if not, just go in the direction of the keyway and see if you need to move it later. what you're shooting for is the portion of the lock holding the shackle in. it'll feel mushy because it's spring loaded. on really, really shit locks you can move this enough to pop the shackle without setting pins.
>3
if it's an unshielded shackle (90% of shackles. seriously. people are retarded), you can fit a thin shim around the shackle and push that same locking bar out of the way. this works for keyed and dial entry locks. you're aiming for something about .010" thick, grab some chinkshit verniers from harbor freight if you want to be technical. a soda can properly cut and hammered thin can suffice if you bend it *perfectly*, which isn't as hard as you think. it's not worth the nicks and cuts though, just buy some .010" and ideally some .060" or .045" feeler gage off of amazon. you can make custom picks with the .060". idk if it's exactly .060", you're not a machinist so it doesn't matter, just find something thin enough. use your harbor freight chinkshit verniers and measure your existing picks if you want to make your own picks.

many a video has been made on this. combination locks suck, no one who's serious about security uses them. i was able to figure out how to crack a hyper tough combination lock in about 5 minutes before i dremeled it open to see how it works (hint: all the internals are made of plastic. you could probably force the fucker open after putting it in your mom's tea water). basically the idea is that if you pull up on the shackle and move the dial, you'll set it in the gates unless there's a false set. even if it's a false set you just push the fucker through. then you just pull the shackle open. i don't have the knack for it because it's just weird to me, but any autist who is dedicated can figure it out and then be able to crack 100% of all combination locks ever without any tools. not that you should even bother because they're all retardedly easy to shim open.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2538244
door locks can be picky, but you might get lucky like >>2538679 did. most door locks of acceptable quality have special security pins in them. serrated pins create a false set by falling into place on cuts in the pin, so it feels like you've set the pin but you really haven't. you can keep pushing it through until it sets, usually. mushroom and spool pins are uncommon, but they're brilliantly designed: if you get a false set, it's entirely possible that you'll have to reset the lock and try again. they stick against the lock body when pressure is applied, and wedge themselves in.

take a look at lockpickinglawyer if you want to get a better idea about security pins. if iwere you, i'd just try to single point pick it like a padlock. just remember that the SC1 and KW1 keyways most commonly used in america for doors are better designed than the M1 keyway, and have an additional 2 pins to contend with.
